title: Behavioral Analysis in Virtual Reality
brief: VR research analyzing user interaction quit patterns via behavioral in immersive environments.

subtitles.title: Project Description
subtitles.content: This project builds interpretable early-quit detectors from VR head-movement telemetry. We extract quaternion-based head rotations (and positions when available) from gameplay logs, convert them to per-frame Euler deltas, and segment the stream into direction-consistent intervals in yaw, pitch, and roll. These interval durations and movement magnitudes are then binned on power-of-two time scales to produce length-invariant histograms of “how often” and “how long” different kinds of head turns occur. Using these features, we construct balanced session-level datasets in HDF5 and train group-aware classifiers (Random Forest, XGBoost, Logistic Regression) to distinguish completing vs. quitting sessions, with t-tests, simple hand-crafted detectors, SHAP, and partial-dependence plots used to interpret which rotation patterns are most predictive.

subtitles.title: My Responsibility
subtitles.content:
Implemented the head-rotation feature pipeline from raw VR telemetry
Constructed balanced session-level datasets (quit vs. non-quit)
Trained and compared multiple classifiers (Random Forest, XGBoost, Logistic Regression)

Ran SHAP and other interpretability analyses to identify which movement patterns distinguish finishing players from early quitters

subtitles.title: Tech Stack
subtitles.content: Python, NumPy, pandas, SciPy, scikit-learn, XGBoost, h5py (HDF5), matplotlib
